trial_identification.scientifictitle: The immunomodulatory effects of omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids : role in allergy prevention

interventions.interventions:
Children will be randomised to receive n-3 rich fish oil (280mg docosahexanoic acid [DHA]/day; 110mg eicosapentanoic acid [EPA]/day orally; Meg 3 Ocean Nutrition, Canada) daily for the first 6 months of life.
The capsules are identical in appearance. Peppermint flavour has been added to both fish oil and placebo capsules.
interventions.comparator: Placebo (olive oil, Ocean Nutrition, Canada) daily for the first 6 months of life.

primaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at 1, 2.5 and 5 years of age
Assessed at 1, 2.5 and 5 years of age

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: 1) maternal asthma or hayfever, and atopy confirmed by skin testing (to common allergens); and 2) maternal age
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Infants will be excluded if: 1) their mothers normal dietary intake exceeds 2 meals of fish per week 2) there are any significant pregnancy or neonatal complications including prematurity of < 36 weeks), or 3) parental smoking.

trial_design.concealment: Allocation was concealed and involved contacting the holder of the allocation schedule who was "off-site".
trial_design.sequence: Eligible infants will be stratified by type of maternal atopy (asthma / other allergy), paternal atopic history and parity, and randomised to placebo or treatment groups. This will be performed by staff who are not involved in clinical or laboratory assessments.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: In this study we will compare the effects of fish oil (n=165) or placebo (n=165) in early infancy (from 0-6 months of age) on the risk of developing allergic sensitisation or allergic disease in early childhood. Both study groups will include children deemed to be at high risk of allergic disease (based on maternal allergy history).

contact.name: Dr Jan Dunstan
contact.address: School of Paediatrics and Child Health Princess Margaret Hospital Subiaco 6008 WA
